ud6.4:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud6.4:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud6.4:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā nānātitthiyasamaṇabrāhmaṇaparibbājakā sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasanti nānādiṭṭhikā nānākhantikā nānārucikā nānādiṭṭhinissayanissitā.
ud6.4:1.3.eng: Now at that time several ascetics, brahmins, and wanderers who followed various other religions were residing in Sāvatthī, holding different views, beliefs, and opinions, relying on different views.

ud6.4:2.1.eng: There were some ascetics and brahmins who had this doctrine and view:

ud6.4:2.2.eng: “The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.”

ud6.4:3.1.eng: Others held views such as the following, each regarding their own view as true and others as silly.

ud6.4:6.2.pli: “taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīraṃ, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.4:6.2.eng: “The soul and the body are one and the same.”

ud6.4:7.2.pli: “aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīraṃ, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.4:7.2.eng: “The soul is one thing, the body another.”

ud6.4:8.2.pli: “hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.4:8.2.eng: “A realized one still exists after death.”

ud6.4:9.2.pli: “na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.4:9.2.eng: “A realized one no longer exists after death.”

ud6.4:10.2.pli: “hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.4:10.2.eng: “A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death.”

ud6.4:11.2.pli: “neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.4:11.2.eng: “A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.”

ud6.4:12.1.pli: Te bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti:
ud6.4:12.1.eng: They were fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words:

ud6.4:12.2.eng: “Such is Truth, such is not Truth!

ud6.4:12.3.eng: Such is not Truth, such is Truth!”

ud6.4:13.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃsu.
ud6.4:13.1.eng: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

ud6.4:13.2.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
ud6.4:13.2.eng: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening. The Buddha said:

ud6.4:13.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:

ud6.4:14.1.pli: “Idha, bhante, sambahulā nānātitthiyasamaṇabrāhmaṇaparibbājakā sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasanti nānādiṭṭhikā nānākhantikā nānārucikā nānādiṭṭhinissayanissitā—

ud6.4:15.3.pli: te bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti:

ud6.4:16.1.eng: “The wanderers of other religions are blind and sightless.

ud6.4:16.2.pli: atthaṃ na jānanti, anatthaṃ na jānanti, dhammaṃ na jānanti, adhammaṃ na jānanti.
ud6.4:16.2.eng: They don’t understand what is beneficial or what is not beneficial, nor what is the truth and what is not the truth.

ud6.4:16.3.pli: Te atthaṃ ajānantā anatthaṃ ajānantā dhammaṃ ajānantā adhammaṃ ajānantā bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti:
ud6.4:16.3.eng: That’s why they are fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words.

ud6.4:17.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, imissāyeva sāvatthiyā aññataro rājā ahosi.
ud6.4:17.1.eng: Once upon a time, mendicants, right here in Sāvatthī there was a certain king.

ud6.4:17.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, so rājā aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:
ud6.4:17.2.eng: Then the king addressed a man,

ud6.4:17.3.pli: ‘ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, yāvatakā sāvatthiyā jaccandhā te sabbe ekajjhaṃ sannipātehī’ti.
ud6.4:17.3.eng: ‘Please, worthy man, gather all those blind from birth throughout Sāvatthī and bring them together in one place.’

ud6.4:17.4.pli: ‘Evaṃ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, so puriso tassa rañño paṭissutvā yāvatakā sāvatthiyā jaccandhā te sabbe gahetvā yena so rājā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ rājānaṃ etadavoca:
ud6.4:17.4.eng: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ that man replied. He did as the king asked, then said to him,

ud6.4:17.5.pli: ‘sannipātitā kho te, deva, yāvatakā sāvatthiyā jaccandhā’ti.
ud6.4:17.5.eng: ‘Your Majesty, the blind people throughout Sāvatthī have been gathered.’

ud6.4:17.6.eng: ‘Well then, my man, show them an elephant.’

ud6.4:17.7.pli: ‘Evaṃ, devā’ti kho, bhikkhave, so puriso tassa rañño paṭissutvā jaccandhānaṃ hatthiṃ dassesi—
ud6.4:17.7.eng: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ that man replied. He did as the king asked.

ud6.4:18.1.eng: To some of the blind people he showed the elephant’s head, saying,

ud6.4:18.3.eng: To some of them he showed the elephant’s ear, saying,

ud6.4:18.5.eng: To some of them he showed the elephant’s tusk, saying,

ud6.4:18.7.eng: To some of them he showed the elephant’s trunk, saying,

ud6.4:18.9.eng: To some of them he showed the elephant’s flank, saying,

ud6.4:18.11.eng: To some of them he showed the elephant’s leg, saying,

ud6.4:18.13.eng: To some of them he showed the elephant’s thigh, saying,

ud6.4:18.15.eng: To some of them he showed the elephant’s tail, saying,

ud6.4:18.17.eng: To some of them he showed the tip of the elephant’s tail, saying,

ud6.4:19.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, so puriso jaccandhānaṃ hatthiṃ dassetvā yena so rājā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ rājānaṃ etadavoca:
ud6.4:19.1.eng: Then he approached the king and said,

ud6.4:19.2.eng: ‘Your Majesty, the blind people have been shown the elephant.

ud6.4:20.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, so rājā yena te jaccandhā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te jaccandhe etadavoca:
ud6.4:20.1.eng: Then the king went up to the blind people and said,

ud6.4:20.3.eng: ‘Yes, Your Majesty, we have been shown the elephant.’

ud6.4:20.4.eng: ‘Then tell us, what kind of thing is an elephant?’

ud6.4:21.1.pli: Yehi, bhikkhave, jaccandhehi hatthissa sīsaṃ diṭṭhaṃ ahosi, te evamāhaṃsu:
ud6.4:21.1.eng: The blind people who had been shown the elephant’s head said,

ud6.4:21.2.eng: ‘Your Majesty, an elephant is like a pot.’

ud6.4:22.1.pli: Yehi, bhikkhave, jaccandhehi hatthissa kaṇṇo diṭṭho ahosi, te evamāhaṃsu:
ud6.4:22.1.eng: Those who had been shown the ear said,

ud6.4:22.2.eng: ‘An elephant is like a winnowing fan.’

ud6.4:23.1.pli: Yehi, bhikkhave, jaccandhehi hatthissa danto diṭṭho ahosi, te evamāhaṃsu:
ud6.4:23.1.eng: Those who had been shown the tusk said,

ud6.4:24.1.pli: Yehi, bhikkhave, jaccandhehi hatthissa soṇḍo diṭṭho ahosi, te evamāhaṃsu:
ud6.4:24.1.eng: Those who had been shown the trunk said,

ud6.4:25.1.pli: Yehi, bhikkhave, jaccandhehi hatthissa kāyo diṭṭho ahosi, te evamāhaṃsu:
ud6.4:25.1.eng: Those who had been shown the flank said,

ud6.4:26.1.pli: Yehi, bhikkhave, jaccandhehi hatthissa pādo diṭṭho ahosi, te evamāhaṃsu:
ud6.4:26.1.eng: Those who had been shown the leg said,

ud6.4:27.1.pli: Yehi, bhikkhave, jaccandhehi hatthissa satthi diṭṭho ahosi, te evamāhaṃsu:
ud6.4:27.1.eng: Those who had been shown the thigh said,

ud6.4:28.1.pli: Yehi, bhikkhave, jaccandhehi hatthissa naṅguṭṭhaṃ diṭṭhaṃ ahosi, te evamāhaṃsu:
ud6.4:28.1.eng: Those who had been shown the tail said,

ud6.4:29.1.pli: Yehi, bhikkhave, jaccandhehi hatthissa vāladhi diṭṭho ahosi, te evamāhaṃsu:
ud6.4:29.1.eng: Those who had been shown the tip of the tail said,

ud6.4:30.1.eng: Saying, ‘Such is an elephant, not such!

ud6.4:30.2.pli: nediso hatthī, ediso hatthī’ti aññamaññaṃ muṭṭhīhi saṃsumbhiṃsu.
ud6.4:30.2.eng: Such is not an elephant, such is!’ they punched each other with their fists.

ud6.4:30.3.pli: Tena ca pana, bhikkhave, so rājā attamano ahosi.
ud6.4:30.3.eng: At that, the king was pleased.

ud6.4:31.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā andhā acakkhukā.
ud6.4:31.1.eng: In the same way, mendicants, the wanderers of other religions are blind and sightless.

ud6.4:31.2.pli: Te atthaṃ na jānanti anatthaṃ na jānanti, dhammaṃ na jānanti adhammaṃ na jānanti.
ud6.4:31.2.eng: They don’t understand what is beneficial or what is not beneficial, nor what is the truth and what is not the truth.

ud6.4:31.3.pli: Te atthaṃ ajānantā anatthaṃ ajānantā, dhammaṃ ajānantā adhammaṃ ajānantā bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti:
ud6.4:31.3.eng: That’s why they are fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words.

ud6.4:31.5.eng: Such is not Truth, such is!’”

ud6.4:32.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud6.4:32.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud6.4:33.4.eng: the folk who see just one part.”

ud6.5:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud6.5:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud6.5:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā nānātitthiyasamaṇabrāhmaṇaparibbājakā sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasanti nānādiṭṭhikā nānākhantikā nānārucikā nānādiṭṭhinissayanissitā.
ud6.5:1.3.eng: Now at that time several ascetics, brahmins, and wanderers who followed various other religions were residing in Sāvatthī, holding different views, beliefs, and opinions, relying on different views.

ud6.5:2.1.eng: There were some ascetics and brahmins who had this doctrine and view:

ud6.5:2.2.pli: “sassato attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:2.2.eng: “The self and the cosmos are eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.”

ud6.5:3.1.eng: Others held views such as the following, each regarding their own view as true and others as silly.

ud6.5:3.2.pli: “asassato attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:3.2.eng: “The self and the cosmos are not eternal.”

ud6.5:4.2.pli: “sassato ca asassato ca attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:4.2.eng: “The self and the cosmos are both eternal and not eternal.”

ud6.5:5.2.pli: “neva sassato nāsassato attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:5.2.eng: “The self and the cosmos are neither eternal nor not eternal.”

ud6.5:6.2.pli: “sayaṅkato attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:6.2.eng: “The self and the cosmos are made by oneself.”

ud6.5:7.2.pli: “paraṅkato attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:7.2.eng: “The self and the cosmos are made by another.”

ud6.5:8.2.pli: “sayaṅkato ca paraṅkato ca attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:8.2.eng: “The self and the cosmos are made by both oneself and another.”

ud6.5:9.2.pli: “asayaṅkāro aparaṅkāro adhiccasamuppanno attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:9.2.eng: “The self and the cosmos have arisen anomalously, not made by oneself or another.”

ud6.5:10.2.pli: “sassataṃ sukhadukkhaṃ attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:10.2.eng: “Pleasure and pain are eternal, and the self and the cosmos.”
ud6.5:10.2.comm: Attā ca loko ca here and following is missing from the parallel passage in DN 29:36.9. I assume it has been inserted in error and translate accordingly.

ud6.5:11.2.pli: “asassataṃ sukhadukkhaṃ attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:11.2.eng: “Pleasure and pain are not eternal, and the self and the cosmos.”

ud6.5:12.2.pli: “sassatañca asassatañca sukhadukkhaṃ attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:12.2.eng: “Pleasure and pain are both eternal and not eternal, and the self and the cosmos.”

ud6.5:13.2.pli: “neva sassataṃ nāsassataṃ sukhadukkhaṃ attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:13.2.eng: “Pleasure and pain are neither eternal nor not eternal, and the self and the cosmos.”

ud6.5:14.2.pli: “sayaṅkataṃ sukhadukkhaṃ attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:14.2.eng: “Pleasure and pain are made by oneself, and the self and the cosmos.”

ud6.5:15.2.pli: “paraṅkataṃ sukhadukkhaṃ attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:15.2.eng: “Pleasure and pain are made by another, and the self and the cosmos.”

ud6.5:16.2.pli: “sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca sukhadukkhaṃ attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:16.2.eng: “Pleasure and pain are made by both oneself and another, and the self and the cosmos.”

ud6.5:17.2.pli: “asayaṅkāraṃ aparaṅkāraṃ adhiccasamuppannaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.5:17.2.eng: “Pleasure and pain have arisen anomalously, not made by oneself or another, and the self and the cosmos.”

ud6.6:14.2.eng: “Pleasure and pain are made by oneself, and the self and the cosmos.”

ud6.6:15.2.pli: “paraṅkataṃ sukhadukkhaṃ attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.6:15.2.eng: “Pleasure and pain are made by another, and the self and the cosmos.”

ud6.6:16.2.pli: “sayaṅkatañca paraṅkatañca sukhadukkhaṃ attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.6:16.2.eng: “Pleasure and pain are made by both oneself and another, and the self and the cosmos.”

ud6.6:17.2.pli: “asayaṅkāraṃ aparaṅkāraṃ adhiccasamuppannaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan”ti.
ud6.6:17.2.eng: “Pleasure and pain have arisen anomalously, not made by oneself or another, and the self and the cosmos.”

ud6.6:18.1.pli: Te bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti:
ud6.6:18.1.eng: They were fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words:

ud6.6:18.3.eng: Such is not Truth, such is Truth!”

ud6.6:19.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃsu.
ud6.6:19.1.eng: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

ud6.6:19.2.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
ud6.6:19.2.eng: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.

ud6.6:19.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:

ud6.6:20.1.pli: “Idha, bhante, sambahulā nānātitthiyasamaṇabrāhmaṇaparibbājakā sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasanti nānādiṭṭhikā nānākhantikā nānārucikā nānādiṭṭhinissayanissitā.

ud6.6:21.2.pli: ‘sassato attā ca loko ca, idameva saccaṃ moghamaññan’ti …pe…

ud6.6:21.3.pli: te bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti:

ud6.6:22.2.pli: Te atthaṃ na jānanti anatthaṃ na jānanti, dhammaṃ na jānanti adhammaṃ na jānanti.

ud6.6:22.3.pli: Te atthaṃ ajānantā anatthaṃ ajānantā, dhammaṃ ajānantā adhammaṃ ajānantā bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti:

ud6.6:23.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud6.6:23.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud6.6:24.2.eng: which is tied up with the other-maker.

ud6.6:24.3.eng: There are some who do not realize this,

ud6.6:24.4.eng: they do not see the dart.

ud6.6:25.1.eng: But when they see this dart,

ud6.6:25.2.eng: they do not think, ‘I make it’,

ud6.6:26.1.eng: These folk are caught up in conceit,

ud6.6:26.2.eng: tied by conceit, shackled by conceit.

ud6.7:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud6.7:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud6.7:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā subhūti bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya avitakkaṃ samādhiṃ samāpajjitvā.
ud6.7:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Subhūti was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight, having attained the immersion free of placing the mind.

ud6.7:2.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ subhūtiṃ avidūre nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya avitakkaṃ samādhiṃ samāpannaṃ.
ud6.7:2.1.eng: The Buddha saw him meditating there.

ud6.7:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud6.7:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud6.7:4.1.eng: “In whom mental vibrations are cleared away,

ud6.7:4.4.eng: having overcome the four yokes, <j>they never return.”
ud6.7:4.4.comm: For “they never return” (na jātu’m’eti) there is a variant reading “go to rebirth” (jātim eti) in Śarīrārthagāthā 32, which here is very close to the Pali. The commentary also acknowledges this variant: ‘Na jāti metī’tipi paṭhanti, so evattho.

ud6.8:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
ud6.8:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

ud6.8:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājagahe dve pūgā aññatarissā gaṇikāya sārattā honti paṭibaddhacittā;
ud6.8:1.3.eng: Now at that time two gangs were both hopelessly in love with a certain courtesan.

ud6.8:1.4.pli: bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ pāṇīhipi upakkamanti, leḍḍūhipi upakkamanti, daṇḍehipi upakkamanti, satthehipi upakkamanti.
ud6.8:1.4.eng: Fighting, quarreling, and disputing, they attacked each other with fists, stones, rods, and swords,

ud6.8:1.5.pli: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti maraṇamattampi dukkhaṃ.
ud6.8:1.5.eng: resulting in death and deadly pain.

ud6.8:2.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya rājagahaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃsu.
ud6.8:2.1.eng: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Rājagaha for alms.

ud6.8:2.2.pli: Rājagahe piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
ud6.8:2.2.eng: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.

ud6.8:2.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:

ud6.8:3.1.pli: “Idha, bhante, rājagahe dve pūgā aññatarissā gaṇikāya sārattā paṭibaddhacittā;

ud6.8:3.2.pli: bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṃ pāṇīhipi upakkamanti, leḍḍūhipi upakkamanti, daṇḍehipi upakkamanti, satthehipi upakkamanti.

ud6.8:3.3.pli: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti maraṇamattampi dukkhan”ti.

ud6.8:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud6.8:4.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud6.8:5.1.pli: “Yañca pattaṃ yañca pattabbaṃ, ubhayametaṃ rajānukiṇṇaṃ, āturassānusikkhato.
ud6.8:5.1.eng: “What has been attained and what is to be attained are both strewn over with dust for that one training while still sick.

ud6.8:5.2.pli: Ye ca sikkhāsārā sīlabbataṃ jīvitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ upaṭṭhānasārā, ayameko anto.
ud6.8:5.2.eng: Those for whom the training is the essence, or precepts and observances, chastity, and service as the essence: this is one extreme.

ud6.8:5.4.eng: ‘There’s nothing wrong with sensual pleasures’: this is the second extreme.

ud6.8:5.5.pli: Iccete ubho antā kaṭasivaḍḍhanā, kaṭasiyo diṭṭhiṃ vaḍḍhenti.
ud6.8:5.5.eng: Thus these two extremes swell the charnel grounds, while the charnel grounds swell wrong view.

ud6.8:5.6.pli: Etete ubho ante anabhiññāya olīyanti eke, atidhāvanti eke.
ud6.8:5.6.eng: Not realizing these two extremes, some get stuck and some overreach.

ud6.8:5.7.pli: Ye ca kho te abhiññāya tatra ca nāhesuṃ, tena ca nāmaññiṃsu, vaṭṭaṃ tesaṃ natthi paññāpanāyā”ti.
ud6.8:5.7.eng: Those who realize these things, who were not found there, who did not conceive by that, there is no cycle of rebirths to be found.”

ud6.9:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud6.9:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud6.9:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā rattandhakāratimisāyaṃ abbhokāse nisinno hoti telappadīpesu jhāyamānesu.
ud6.9:1.3.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was meditating in the open during the dark of night, while oil lamps were burning.

ud6.9:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā adhipātakā tesu telappadīpesu āpātaparipātaṃ anayaṃ āpajjanti, byasanaṃ āpajjanti, anayabyasanaṃ āpajjanti.
ud6.9:2.1.eng: And many moths were falling down and crashing down into the lamps, coming to grief and ruin.

ud6.9:2.2.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā te sambahule adhipātake tesu telappadīpesu āpātaparipātaṃ anayaṃ āpajjante, byasanaṃ āpajjante, anayabyasanaṃ āpajjante.
ud6.9:2.2.eng: The Buddha saw the moths coming to grief.

ud6.9:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud6.9:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud6.9:4.3.eng: Like moths falling in the flame,

ud6.9:4.4.eng: some have become fixed in what is seen or heard.”
